articles.headline: Banks’ Ability to Rig Rates Shows Need for Change
articles.snippet: Evidence that banks manipulated the influential London interbank offered rate for several years has called its usefulness into question.
articles.abstract: Evidence that banks manipulated the influential London interbank offered rate for several years has called its usefulness into question.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is Libor — the London interbank offered rate — an idea whose time has passed? And if so, what can replace it?

articles.headline: Today’s Key to Selling Magazines: A TV Doctor
articles.snippet: The television celebrity Dr. Oz is helping to sell magazines at a time when the industry is struggling to figure out how to appeal to readers.
articles.abstract: The television celebrity Dr. Oz is helping to sell magazines at a time when the industry is struggling to figure out how to appeal to readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samantha Feld does not watch much television. But Ms. Feld, a 23-year-old publicist, is a loyal follower of the television celebrity Dr. Mehmet Oz.

articles.headline: After Delay, OxyContin’s Use in Young Is Under Study
articles.snippet: Hoping to win a six-month extension of protection from generic competition, the maker of OxyContin is renewing a clinical trial.
articles.abstract: Hoping to win a six-month extension of protection from generic competition, the maker of OxyContin is renewing a clinical trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: To learn how best to prescribe powerful drugs to children, Congress passed a law in the 1990s that rewarded drug makers for conducting clinical studies involving children. Among the incentives for cooperating companies was a possible six-month extension of protection from generic competition after a drug’s patent expired.

articles.headline: After Liberté and Égalité, It’s Autopsie
articles.snippet: Philippe Charlier, a physician and anthropologist, is known for his forensic research into some of France’s most famous dead.
articles.abstract: Philippe Charlier, a physician and anthropologist, is known for his forensic research into some of France’s most famous dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARCHES, France — The plastic vial with the red top is Henri IV. The one with the blue top is the never-crowned Louis XVII.

articles.headline: Tech Companies Leave Phone Calls Behind
articles.snippet: Increasingly, social technology businesses are taking an antisocial attitude to callers, making themselves available to customers via e-mail, Twitter messages and Web sites.
articles.abstract: Increasingly, social technology businesses are taking an antisocial attitude to callers, making themselves available to customers via e-mail, Twitter messages and Web sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: Quora is a Web site that crowdsources answers to just about any question imaginable, including “What is the meaning of life?” and “Is it possible to stick someone to the wall with Velcro?” But anyone searching for a phone number for the company is out of luck. Not only is the number unlisted, but the very question “What is the phone number for Quora?” has gone unanswered for months.

articles.headline: A Fancy Financial Adviser Title Does Not Ensure High Standards
articles.snippet: Investors seeking smart advice should be mindful of what a financial adviser is not disclosing to them.
articles.abstract: Investors seeking smart advice should be mindful of what a financial adviser is not disclosing to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most investors don’t realize that when they walk into a bank or brokerage firm branch, the representatives there are essentially free to emblazon their business cards with whatever titles they please — financial consultants, advisers, wealth managers, to name a few. But if you’re looking for someone who is qualified to give smart advice about all aspects of your financial life while keeping costs down, you may not be in the right place.

articles.headline: Braving Areas of Violence, Voters Try to Reshape Libya
articles.snippet: Defying expectations and, in some places, bullets, Libyans voted in the first election after more than four decades under Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
articles.abstract: Defying expectations and, in some places, bullets, Libyans voted in the first election after more than four decades under Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Defying expectations and, in some places, bullets, Libyans across most of the country voted Saturday in the first election after more than four decades of isolation and totalitarianism under Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

articles.headline: The British, at Least, Are Getting Tough
articles.snippet: The Libor scandal involving Barclays points to a need for greater transparency in the world of finance. But Wall Street continues to balk.
articles.abstract: The Libor scandal involving Barclays points to a need for greater transparency in the world of finance. But Wall Street continues to balk.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE unfolding story of how Barclays — and, in all likelihood, other big banks — rigged interest rates is full of telling tidbits about the way Wall Street works. It also represents yet another teachable moment.

articles.headline: A Northwest Pipeline to Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: The University of Washington’s reputation as an incubator of tech talent is growing — and so have the job offers from the famed area further down the West Coast.
articles.abstract: The University of Washington’s reputation as an incubator of tech talent is growing — and so have the job offers from the famed area further down the West Coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seattle

articles.headline: Has ‘Organic’ Been Oversized?
articles.snippet: Large corporations now dominate in organic foods, and some people think this has led to a watering down of the industry.
articles.abstract: Large corporations now dominate in organic foods, and some people think this has led to a watering down of the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

articles.headline: In Ads, the Workers Rise Up ... and Go to Lunch
articles.snippet: In different ways, with a touch of humor, advertising for Las Vegas, McDonald’s, Gold Peak Tea and Huffy bicycles addresses the frustrations of hard-pressed workers.
articles.abstract: In different ways, with a touch of humor, advertising for Las Vegas, McDonald’s, Gold Peak Tea and Huffy bicycles addresses the frustrations of hard-pressed workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The woman had had enough. Amid ringing phones and clicking keyboards she climbs up on her desk and shouts through her speakerphone: “I have 47 vacation days. That’s insane.”

articles.headline: Arab Uprisings Point Up Flaws in Global Court
articles.snippet: The failure to act against some autocratic leaders challenged by the Arab Spring is emboldening critics who see the court as part of a deeply undemocratic international order.
articles.abstract: The failure to act against some autocratic leaders challenged by the Arab Spring is emboldening critics who see the court as part of a deeply undemocratic international order.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — It was exactly the kind of case the International Criminal Court was created to investigate: Yemen’s autocratic leader was clinging to power, turning his security forces’ guns on unarmed protesters. Hundreds were left dead, and many more were maimed.

articles.headline: Tax-Exempt Groups Shield Political Gifts of Businesses
articles.snippet: Corporations are funding policy organizations that are free of the disclosure rules applying to parties, candidates and PACs.
articles.abstract: Corporations are funding policy organizations that are free of the disclosure rules applying to parties, candidates and PACs.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Electric Power, one of the country’s largest utilities, gave $1 million last November to the Founding Fund, a new tax-exempt group that intends to raise most of its money from corporations and push for limited government.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: On Tricky Terrain of Class, Contrasting Paths
articles.snippet: Class politics are surfacing in increasingly visible ways in the campaign between President Obama and Mitt Romney, presenting big risks and opportunities to both sides.
articles.abstract: Class politics are surfacing in increasingly visible ways in the campaign between President Obama and Mitt Romney, presenting big risks and opportunities to both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The complex and fraught politics of wealth and class, undercurrents all along in the race between President Obama and Mitt Romney, are surfacing in increasingly visible ways in the presidential campaign, presenting big risks and opportunities to both sides.

articles.headline: Chinese Premier Urges Action to Spur Economy
articles.snippet: Premier Wen Jiabao of China on Sunday called for the government to become more aggressive in using fiscal and monetary tools to respond to a slowing economy.
articles.abstract: Premier Wen Jiabao of China on Sunday called for the government to become more aggressive in using fiscal and monetary tools to respond to a slowing economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Premier Wen Jiabao of China warned on Sunday of “huge downward pressure” on the Chinese economy, in the clearest expression yet of concern at the top of the country’s leadership about a sharp slowdown in recent months.

articles.headline: Election Results in Libya Break an Islamist Wave
articles.snippet: The post-Arab Spring rise of Islamist leaders appeared to bypass Libya, where a coalition led by a Western-educated political scientist led the early vote count.
articles.abstract: The post-Arab Spring rise of Islamist leaders appeared to bypass Libya, where a coalition led by a Western-educated political scientist led the early vote count.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — A coalition led by a Western-educated political scientist appeared on Sunday to be beating its Islamist rivals in Libya’s first election after Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, breaking an Islamist wave that swept across neighboring Egypt, Tunisia and Morocco in the aftermath of the Arab Spring uprisings.

articles.headline: Egypt’s President Orders Return of Parliament
articles.snippet: President Mohamed Morsi’s decree appeared to be a bold effort to claim authority, raising the specter of confrontation with Egypt’s military and courts.
articles.abstract: President Mohamed Morsi’s decree appeared to be a bold effort to claim authority, raising the specter of confrontation with Egypt’s military and courts.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt on Sunday unexpectedly ordered the country’s Islamist-led Parliament to reconvene, challenging earlier decisions by Egypt’s most powerful generals and judges to dissolve the legislative body.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: The Fissures Are Growing for Papers
articles.snippet: Between operational fiascos and flailing attempts to slash costs on the fly, it’s clear that the print newspaper business is struggling to stay afloat.
articles.abstract: Between operational fiascos and flailing attempts to slash costs on the fly, it’s clear that the print newspaper business is struggling to stay afloat.
articles.lead_paragraph: While the rest of us were burning hot dogs on the grill last week, the newspaper industry seemed to be lighting itself on fire.

articles.headline: More Demands on Cell Carriers in Surveillance
articles.snippet: Cellphone carriers said they responded to 1.3 million demands last year from law enforcement agencies seeking text messages, caller locations and other information on subscribers.
articles.abstract: Cellphone carriers said they responded to 1.3 million demands last year from law enforcement agencies seeking text messages, caller locations and other information on subscribers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the first public accounting of its kind, cellphone carriers reported that they responded to a startling 1.3 million demands for subscriber information last year from law enforcement agencies seeking text messages, caller locations and other information in the course of investigations.

articles.headline: BlackBerry’s Latest Delay Could Lead to Lawsuits
articles.snippet: Several securities law experts say the delay in the BlackBerry 10, and overly optimistic remarks by Research in Motion’s chief executive, may make the company a target of shareholder lawsuits.
articles.abstract: Several securities law experts say the delay in the BlackBerry 10, and overly optimistic remarks by Research in Motion’s chief executive, may make the company a target of shareholder lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A friendly crowd is unlikely to greet Thorsten Heins on Tuesday, when he makes his first appearance as chief executive at the annual meeting here of Research in Motion.

articles.headline: Converting TV Laughs Into Dollars
articles.snippet: Given the changing landscape of the television business, Comedy Central will soon introduce a merchandising division intended to cash in on its identity as a destination for laughs.
articles.abstract: Given the changing landscape of the television business, Comedy Central will soon introduce a merchandising division intended to cash in on its identity as a destination for laughs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Given the changing landscape of the television business, the Comedy Central channel has decided it now makes sense to sell T-shirts as well as laughs.

articles.headline: In the Footsteps of Marvel
articles.snippet: Valiant Entertainment, a comics company that was a force in the 1990s but later fell victim to bankruptcy, is hoping to cash in on Hollywood’s interest in superheroes, as Marvel did before it.
articles.abstract: Valiant Entertainment, a comics company that was a force in the 1990s but later fell victim to bankruptcy, is hoping to cash in on Hollywood’s interest in superheroes, as Marvel did before it.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Can Valiant Entertainment pull off a Marvel-style comeback?

articles.headline: Obama Poised for New Fight With G.O.P. Over Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: President Obama will call for a one-year break only for people making less than $250,000, a limit opposed by Republicans and at odds with a higher cap favored by some Democrats.
articles.abstract: President Obama will call for a one-year break only for people making less than $250,000, a limit opposed by Republicans and at odds with a higher cap favored by some Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a torpid job market and a fragile economy threatening his re-election chances, President Obama is changing the subject to tax fairness, calling for a one-year extension of the Bush-era tax cuts for people making less than $250,000.

articles.headline: Egypt’s Military and President Escalate Their Power Struggle
articles.snippet: Egypt’s highest court and its most senior generals dismissed President Mohamed Morsi’s order to restore the dissolved Parliament, reflecting dueling claims to the country’s emerging politics.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s highest court and its most senior generals dismissed President Mohamed Morsi’s order to restore the dissolved Parliament, reflecting dueling claims to the country’s emerging politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s highest court and its most senior generals on Monday dismissed President Mohamed Morsi’s order to restore the dissolved Parliament as an affront to the rule of law, escalating a raw contest for supremacy between the competing camps.
